abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Cash Crop Development
            Project for Nepal was unsatisfactory. The project did not
            achieve its main objectives, its impact has been modest,
            sustainability is unlikely, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed unsatisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, in project design, complex
            institutional arrangements should be avoided to minimize
            problems of project coordination, management, and
            monitoring. Second, care should be taken in assessing the
            data of crop yields, the opportunities for increasing both
            yields and areas under cultivation, and the availability of
            relevant technology. Third, policy conditionality should be
            included in the design of crop specific projects to maintain
            the competitiveness of these commodities with potential
            substitutes. Fourth, if key institutional arrangements are
            not implemented, more decisive action should be taken by IDA
            to induce corrective action. Fifth, for complex projects, it
            is essential that a full time coordinator be appointed for a
            sufficiently long duration to provide the needed continuity.
            Sixth, research programs should be tailored initially to the
            needs of the predominant farming system, to be followed
            later by more specialized programs. Lastly, adequate staff
            allocations should be made to ensure timely compliance with
            auditing covenants.
